awd_titl_txt: CAREER: RUI: NetDA -- Protein Network-Based Software for Disease Analysis Using Cliques, Bipartite Graphs, and Diffusion Kernels
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate and analyze the complex phenomena of disease progression at the protein network level. A software tool, NetDA (Network-based Disease Analysis) to understand the essential mechanisms of disease progression as transitions between disease stages will be developed. The outcome of this study will help not only in early diagnosis of a disease but also in drug design specific for a disease stage.  Undergraduate students will be involved in the research.

The process of disease progression will be analyzed as an event-schedule-like structure, where a) each event representing a disease stage completed by a group of proteins will be analyzed in terms of clique and clique-like graphs, b) transfer of signals from one stage to the next will be analyzed using bipartite and bipartite-like graphs, and c) the strength of signals will be analyzed using diffusion kernels. The outcome of this study will help not only in early diagnosis of a disease but also in drug design specific for a disease stage.  The project will integrate research into the undergraduate curriculum by assigning projects, in courses already developed by the PI, to solve problems in the proposed work. The project will provide research experience for undergraduate students using focused short projects during both academic year and summer.   There is also a plan for the project to provide research experience for middle and high school students. The project will also develop approaches to introduce K-12 students to programming concepts as well as bioinformatics with the help of graphics. A summer institute is also planned to enhance student participation.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The hypothesis of this project was that a set of genes or proteins work together by forming a clique or clique-like graphs in developing a disease, and different sets of genes work together in different stages of a disease. The second hypothesis was that different sets of disease genes crosstalk by forming a bipartite-like graph structure. Our analysis of gene co-expression networks of different cancers, including Brain, Breast, and Colon cancer, has not only tested these hypotheses but also revealed significant findings. We found that cliques and bipartite graphs are the fundamental building blocks of cancer at the protein network level. Moreover, we demonstrated the existence of subnetwork biomarkers for cancer at the protein network level, which consist of cliques and bipartite-like structures. These network biomarkers carry the prognostic characteristics of cancer, meaning they can effectively distinguish between high-risk and low-risk groups of patients. Our study using weighted gene co-expression network analysis (WGCNA) discovered network modules corresponding to both cancer stage-specific and stage-to-stage trajectory for breast cancer, providing a deeper understanding of the disease.

We extend the scope of this project to show that not only the clique-like structures but also other types of community of proteins at the protein network level could be prognostic biomarkers. Our experiment on gene co-expression networks of Brain, Breast, and Colon cancers utilizing community-based algorithms discovered conserved communities, which are network biomarkers with prognostic capability.

Though we started this project with the discovery of subnetwork biomarkers from gene co-expression networks using basic graph theory-based concepts clique and bipartite graphs, eventually, it panned out to both directions of (a) data utilization from single omics to multi-omics and (b) methodology development from graph theory to feature selection, explainable AI, and graph neural network-based approaches.

Leveraging a feature selection-based deep learning approach, concrete autoencoder (CAE), we discovered prognostic long non-coding RNAs for 12 cancers. Using CAE-based approaches, we also discovered a set of ~100 cancer Glycome genes that dictate the origins of 33 different cancer types and key genes to evaluate the level of intratumor heterogeneity. Using explainable AI, we discovered patient-specific significant biomarkers leading to precision medicine for lung cancer. Finally, we developed a multi-omics integration approach utilizing graph attention networks (MOGAT) for cancer subtype prediction. We did the integration analysis using 2 to 8 omics data types. Our results showed that three omics produced the optimum outcome in breast cancer subtype prediction. Adding more than three omics does not improve the performance at all. So, we do not need too many omics for cancer precision medicine.

To date, the project has not only produced 20 peer-reviewed publications, with further papers in development, but also significantly impacted education and tool development in our field. Four PhD students (2 graduated and 2 current), 14 masters (12 graduated and 2 current), 65 undergraduates (senior capstone project), 3 REU, 2 high school teachers, and 8 K-12 students were trained in Algorithmic Cancer Biology, Machine Learning, and Artificial Intelligence. This training has not only equipped these individuals with valuable knowledge and skills but also inspired them to contribute to the field. Undergraduate students, through capstone projects, developed a Cytoscape app, CyFinder, that can isolate clique and bipartite graph structures and network modules or biomarkers from gene or protein networks for cancer, thereby contributing to the development of tools for cancer research and diagnosis.

 


Last Modified: 09/29/2024
Modified by: Ananda M Mondal
